content.text: Perfect! I found the Xcode 26 system prompts documentation. Let me fetch the latest iOS 26 Liquid Glass documentation:

input.topic: glassEffect Liquid Glass iOS 26 material glass buttons

content.text:
================
CODE SNIPPETS
================
TITLE: Apply Basic Liquid Glass Effect in SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: Applies the default Liquid Glass effect to a Text view. This modifier adds a glass-like appearance with blurring and reflection properties.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/SwiftUI-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
Text("Hello, World!")
    .font(.title)
    .padding()
    .glassEffect()
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Enable Interactive Liquid Glass in SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: Applies a Liquid Glass effect with interactivity enabled to a Text view, allowing it to react to touch and pointer interactions. This can be done explicitly or more concisely.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/SwiftUI-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
Text("Hello, World!")
    .font(.title)
    .padding()
    .glassEffect(.regular.interactive(true))
```

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
Text("Hello, World!")
    .font(.title)
    .padding()
    .glassEffect(.regular.interactive())
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Customize Liquid Glass Properties in SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: Applies a Liquid Glass effect with custom properties, including a regular variant, an orange tint, and interactivity, to a Text view. This demonstrates how to configure the appearance and behavior of the glass effect.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/SwiftUI-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
Text("Hello, World!")
    .font(.title)
    .padding()
    .glassEffect(.regular.tint(.orange).interactive())
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: SwiftUI Custom Badge with Liquid Glass
DESCRIPTION: Provides an example of creating a custom badge view in SwiftUI using Liquid Glass effects. The `BadgeView` uses a `ZStack` to layer shapes and symbols, applying a glass effect with rounded corners.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/SwiftUI-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: Swift
CODE:
```
import SwiftUI

struct BadgeView: View {
    let symbol: String
    let color: Color
    
    var body: some View {
        ZStack {
            Image(systemName: "hexagon.fill")
                .foregroundColor(color)
                .font(.system(size: 50))
            
            Image(systemName: symbol)
                .foregroundColor(.white)
                .font(.system(size: 30))
        }
        .glassEffect(.regular, in: .rect(cornerRadius: 16))
    }
}

struct BadgeContainerView: View {
    var body: some View {
        GlassEffectContainer(spacing: 20) {
            HStack(spacing: 20) {
                BadgeView(symbol: "star.fill", color: .blue)
                BadgeView(symbol: "heart.fill", color: .red)
                BadgeView(symbol: "leaf.fill", color: .green)
            }
        }
    }
}

#Preview {
    BadgeContainerView()
}
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Unite Multiple Glass Effects with glassEffectUnion in SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: Applies the `glassEffectUnion` modifier to individual Image views within a `GlassEffectContainer` to group them under a single Liquid Glass effect. This is useful for dynamic views or views not in standard stacks.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/SwiftUI-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
@Namespace private var namespace

// Later in your view:
GlassEffectContainer(spacing: 20.0) {
    HStack(spacing: 20.0) {
        ForEach(symbolSet.indices, id: \.self) {
            Image(systemName: symbolSet[item])
                .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
                .font(.system(size: 36))
                .glassEffect()
                .glassEffectUnion(id: item < 2 ? "1" : "2", namespace: namespace)
        }
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Use GlassEffectContainer for Multiple Effects in SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: Uses `GlassEffectContainer` to manage multiple Liquid Glass effects within an HStack, controlling spacing between elements. This improves rendering performance and enables blending effects.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/SwiftUI-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
GlassEffectContainer(spacing: 40.0) {
    HStack(spacing: 40.0) {
        Image(systemName: "scribble.variable")
            .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
            .font(.system(size: 36))
            .glassEffect()

        Image(systemName: "eraser.fill")
            .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
            .font(.system(size: 36))
            .glassEffect()
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Customize Liquid Glass Shape in SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: Applies a Liquid Glass effect with a custom rectangular shape and corner radius to a Text view. This allows for more specific visual styling beyond the default capsule shape.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/SwiftUI-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
Text("Hello, World!")
    .font(.title)
    .padding()
    .glassEffect(in: .rect(cornerRadius: 16.0))
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: SwiftUI Background Extension Effect
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to use the background extension effect in SwiftUI to stretch content behind elements like sidebars or inspectors. This is achieved by placing content within a `.background` modifier.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/SwiftUI-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: Swift
CODE:
```
NavigationSplitView {
    // Sidebar content
} detail: {
    // Detail content
        .background {
            // Background content that extends under the sidebar
        }
}
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: SwiftUI Implementing Liquid Glass Design
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the implementation of a new Liquid Glass visual material within SwiftUI applications. This snippet focuses on leveraging SwiftUI's declarative UI framework to achieve modern design aesthetics.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/README.md

LANGUAGE: Swift
CODE:
```
This is a placeholder for code related to SwiftUI Liquid Glass Design. Specific implementation details would be found in the linked markdown file.
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: SwiftUI Glass Button Styling
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to apply the built-in `.glass` button style in SwiftUI for a standard glass-themed button. This modifier provides a default appearance for buttons using Liquid Glass.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/SwiftUI-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: Swift
CODE:
```
Button("Click Me") {
    // Action
}
.buttonStyle(.glass)
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: SwiftUI Morphing Transitions with Namespace
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates creating morphing transitions between views using the `@Namespace` property wrapper and `glassEffectID` in SwiftUI. This allows views with Liquid Glass to animate smoothly when added or removed from the view hierarchy.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/SwiftUI-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: Swift
CODE:
```
import SwiftUI

struct ContentView: View {
    @State private var isExpanded: Bool = false
    @Namespace private var namespace

    var body: some View {
        VStack {
            GlassEffectContainer(spacing: 40.0) {
                HStack(spacing: 40.0) {
                    Image(systemName: "scribble.variable")
                        .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
                        .font(.system(size: 36))
                        .glassEffect()
                        .glassEffectID("pencil", in: namespace)

                    if isExpanded {
                        Image(systemName: "eraser.fill")
                            .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
                            .font(.system(size: 36))
                            .glassEffect()
                            .glassEffectID("eraser", in: namespace)
                    }
                }
            }

            Button("Toggle") {
                withAnimation {
                    isExpanded.toggle()
                }
            }
            .buttonStyle(.glass)
        }
        .padding()
    }
}

#Preview {
    ContentView()
}
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Detect Widget Rendering Mode in SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use the `@Environment(.widgetRenderingMode)` property to detect the current rendering mode of a widget and conditionally apply different layouts.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/WidgetKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
struct MyWidgetView: View {
    @Environment(\.widgetRenderingMode) var renderingMode
    
    var body: some View {
        if renderingMode == .accented {
            // Layout optimized for accented mode
        } else {
            // Standard full-color layout
        }
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Create Basic Liquid Glass Effect in Swift
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a simple Liquid Glass effect using `UIVisualEffectView` and `UIGlassEffect`. This involves initializing the effect, creating a view to host it, and adding content to the view.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/UIKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
let glassEffect = UIGlassEffect()
let visualEffectView = UIVisualEffectView(effect: glassEffect)
visualEffectView.frame = CGRect(x: 50, y: 100, width: 300, height: 200)
visualEffectView.layer.cornerRadius = 20
visualEffectView.clipsToBounds = true

let label = UILabel()
label.text = "Liquid Glass"
label.textAlignment = .center
label.frame = visualEffectView.bounds
visualEffectView.contentView.addSubview(label)

view.addSubview(visualEffectView)
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Unify Liquid Glass Effects for Specific Widget Elements
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to create a unified Liquid Glass effect across a subset of widget elements using the `.glassEffectUnion()` modifier within a `GlassEffectContainer`. This is useful for grouping elements that should visually interact as a single unit, identified by a common ID and namespace.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/WidgetKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
GlassEffectContainer(spacing: 20.0) {
    HStack(spacing: 20.0) {
        ForEach(items.indices, id: \.self) {
            Image(systemName: items[item])
                .frame(width: 60, height: 60)
                .glassEffect()
                .glassEffectUnion(id: item < 2 ? "group1" : "group2", namespace: namespace)
        }
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Apply Default and Custom Liquid Glass Effects to Custom Widget Elements
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to apply default and customized Liquid Glass effects to Text, Image, and Button elements within custom widget views. The `.glassEffect()` modifier applies a default effect, while `.glassEffect(.regular, in: .rect(cornerRadius: 12))` allows for custom shape and style. A `.buttonStyle(.glass)` is also shown for glass-like button appearances.

TITLE: Create Toolbar with Liquid Glass Effect in Swift
DESCRIPTION: This Swift function demonstrates how to set up a macOS window with a custom toolbar that features a liquid glass effect. It involves creating an `NSWindow`, configuring an `NSToolbar`, and adding an `NSGlassEffectView` to the window's content view to achieve the desired visual effect. The code also includes placeholder implementations for `NSToolbarDelegate` methods.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/AppKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
func setupToolbarWithGlassEffect() {
    // Create a window
    let window = NSWindow(contentRect: NSRect(x: 0, y: 0, width: 800, height: 600),
                         styleMask: [.titled, .closable, .miniaturizable, .resizable],
                         backing: .buffered,
                         defer: false)
    
    // Create a custom toolbar
    let toolbar = NSToolbar(identifier: "GlassToolbar")
    toolbar.displayMode = .iconAndLabel
    toolbar.delegate = self // Implement NSToolbarDelegate
    
    // Set the toolbar on the window
    window.toolbar = toolbar
    
    // Create a glass effect view for the toolbar area
    let toolbarHeight: CGFloat = 50.0
    let glassView = NSGlassEffectView(frame: NSRect(x: 0, y: window.contentView!.bounds.height - toolbarHeight,
                                                  width: window.contentView!.bounds.width, height: toolbarHeight))
    glassView.autoresizingMask = [.width, .minYMargin]
    
    // Add the glass view to the window's content view
    window.contentView?.addSubview(glassView)
    
    // Make the window visible
    window.makeKeyAndOrderFront(nil)
}

// Implement NSToolbarDelegate methods
extension MyViewController: NSToolbarDelegate {
    func toolbar(_ toolbar: NSToolbar, itemForItemIdentifier itemIdentifier: NSToolbarItem.Identifier, willBeInsertedIntoToolbar flag: Bool) -> NSToolbarItem? {
        // Create toolbar items
        let item = NSToolbarItem(itemIdentifier: itemIdentifier)
        item.label = "Action"
        item.image = NSImage(systemSymbolName: "star.fill", accessibilityDescription: nil)
        item.action = #selector(toolbarItemClicked(_:))
        return item
    }
    
    func toolbarDefaultItemIdentifiers(_ toolbar: NSToolbar) -> [NSToolbarItem.Identifier] {
        return ["item1", "item2", "item3"].map { NSToolbarItem.Identifier($0) }
    }
    
    func toolbarAllowedItemIdentifiers(_ toolbar: NSToolbar) -> [NSToolbarItem.Identifier] {
        return toolbarDefaultItemIdentifiers(toolbar)
    }
    
    @objc func toolbarItemClicked(_ sender: Any) {
        // Handle toolbar item clicks
    }
}
```

TITLE: Create NSGlassEffectContainerView with Multiple Glass Views (Swift)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to set up an NSGlassEffectContainerView to hold and manage multiple NSGlassEffectView instances. It configures the container's spacing to control the merging effect of adjacent glass views and adds labels to each glass view, centering them using Auto Layout constraints.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/AppKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
func setupGlassContainer() {
    // Create a container view
    let containerView = NSGlassEffectContainerView(frame: NSRect(x: 20, y: 20, width: 400, height: 200))
    
    // Set spacing to control when glass effects merge
    containerView.spacing = 40.0
    
    // Create a content view to hold our glass views
    let contentView = NSView(frame: containerView.bounds)
    contentView.autoresizingMask = [.width, .height]
    containerView.contentView = contentView
    
    // Create first glass view
    let glassView1 = NSGlassEffectView(frame: NSRect(x: 20, y: 50, width: 150, height: 100))
    glassView1.cornerRadius = 12.0
    let label1 = NSTextField(labelWithString: "Glass View 1")
    label1.translatesAutoresizingMaskIntoConstraints = false
    glassView1.contentView = label1
    
    // Create second glass view
    let glassView2 = NSGlassEffectView(frame: NSRect(x: 190, y: 50, width: 150, height: 100))
    glassView2.cornerRadius = 12.0
    let label2 = NSTextField(labelWithString: "Glass View 2")
    label2.translatesAutoresizingMaskIntoConstraints = false
    glassView2.contentView = label2
    
    // Add glass views to the content view
    contentView.addSubview(glassView1)
    contentView.addSubview(glassView2)
    
    // Center labels in their respective glass views
    if let contentView1 = glassView1.contentView, let contentView2 = glassView2.contentView {
        NSLayoutConstraint.activate([
            label1.centerXAnchor.constraint(equalTo: contentView1.centerXAnchor),
            label1.centerYAnchor.constraint(equalTo: contentView1.centerYAnchor),
            label2.centerXAnchor.constraint(equalTo: contentView2.centerXAnchor),
            label2.centerYAnchor.constraint(equalTo: contentView2.centerYAnchor)
        ])
    }
    
    // Add the container to your view hierarchy
    view.addSubview(containerView)
}
```

TITLE: Create a Reusable Glass Card View (Swift)
DESCRIPTION: This Swift code defines a reusable `GlassCardView` class that utilizes `UIVisualEffectView` to create a glass-like appearance. It allows customization of tint color and interactivity, and provides a method to add content views to the card.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/UIKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
class GlassCardView: UIView {
    private let visualEffectView: UIVisualEffectView
    private let contentView = UIView()
    
    init(frame: CGRect, tintColor: UIColor? = nil, isInteractive: Bool = false) {
        let glassEffect = UIGlassEffect()
        glassEffect.tintColor = tintColor
        glassEffect.isInteractive = isInteractive
        
        visualEffectView = UIVisualEffectView(effect: glassEffect)
        
        super.init(frame: frame)
        
        setupViews()
    }
    
    required init?(coder: NSCoder) {
        let glassEffect = UIGlassEffect()
        visualEffectView = UIVisualEffectView(effect: glassEffect)
        
        super.init(coder: coder)
        
        setupViews()
    }
    
    private func setupViews() {
        visualEffectView.frame = bounds
        visualEffectView.autoresizingMask = [.flexibleWidth, .flexibleHeight]
        visualEffectView.layer.cornerRadius = 20
        visualEffectView.clipsToBounds = true
        addSubview(visualEffectView)
        
        contentView.frame = bounds
        contentView.autoresizingMask = [.flexibleWidth, .flexibleHeight]
        contentView.backgroundColor = .clear
        addSubview(contentView)
    }
    
    func addContent(_ view: UIView) {
        view.frame = contentView.bounds
        view.autoresizingMask = [.flexibleWidth, .flexibleHeight]
        contentView.addSubview(view)
    }
}

// Usage:
let cardView = GlassCardView(
    frame: CGRect(x: 50, y: 100, width: 300, height: 200),
    tintColor: UIColor.systemBlue.withAlphaComponent(0.2),
    isInteractive: true
)

let label = UILabel()
label.text = "Glass Card"
label.textAlignment = .center
label.textColor = .white
cardView.addContent(label)

view.addSubview(cardView)
```

TITLE: Animate Glass Views within NSGlassEffectContainerView (Swift)
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to animate the position of glass views within an NSGlassEffectContainerView using Swift's animation framework. By changing the frame of a glass view, this example demonstrates how the container's spacing property can trigger merging effects between adjacent glass views.

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
func animateGlassViews() {
    // Assuming we have glassView1 and glassView2 in a container
    
    NSAnimationContext.runAnimationGroup { context in
        context.duration = 0.5
        context.timingFunction = CAMediaTimingFunction(name: .easeInEaseOut)
        
        // Animate the position of glassView2 to move closer to glassView1
        // This will trigger the merging effect when they get within the container's spacing
        glassView2.animator().frame = NSRect(x: 100, y: 50, width: 150, height: 100)
    }
}
```

TITLE: Create Custom Glass Button with Hover Effect (Swift)
DESCRIPTION: Implements a custom NSButton subclass in Swift that features a glass effect using NSGlassEffectView. It includes hover effects that change the tint color of the glass view when the mouse enters or exits the button area. The button is configured with rounded bezels and no border.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/AppKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
class GlassButton: NSButton {
    private let glassView = NSGlassEffectView()
    
    override init(frame frameRect: NSRect) {
        super.init(frame: frameRect)
        setupGlassEffect()
    }
    
    required init?(coder: NSCoder) {
        super.init(coder: coder)
        setupGlassEffect()
    }
    
    private func setupGlassEffect() {
        // Configure the button
        self.title = "Glass Button"
        self.bezelStyle = .rounded
        self.isBordered = false
        
        // Configure the glass view
        glassView.frame = self.bounds
        glassView.autoresizingMask = [.width, .height]
        glassView.cornerRadius = 8.0
        
        // Insert the glass view below the button's content
        self.addSubview(glassView, positioned: .below, relativeTo: nil)
    }
    
    override func updateTrackingAreas() {
        super.updateTrackingAreas()
        
        // Add tracking area for hover effects
        let options: NSTrackingArea.Options = [.mouseEnteredAndExited, .activeInActiveApp]
        let trackingArea = NSTrackingArea(rect: bounds, options: options, owner: self, userInfo: nil)
        addTrackingArea(trackingArea)
    }
    
    override func mouseEntered(with event: NSEvent) {
        super.mouseEntered(with: event)
        // Change appearance on hover
        NSAnimationContext.runAnimationGroup { context in
            context.duration = 0.2
            glassView.animator().tintColor = NSColor.systemBlue.withAlphaComponent(0.2)
        }
    }
    
    override func mouseExited(with event: NSEvent) {
        super.mouseExited(with: event)
        // Restore original appearance
        NSAnimationContext.runAnimationGroup { context in
            context.duration = 0.2
            glassView.animator().tintColor = nil
        }
    }
}
```

TITLE: Handle Mouse Events with NSGlassEffectView in Swift
DESCRIPTION: This Swift code defines an `InteractiveGlassView` that inherits from `NSGlassEffectView`. It sets up tracking areas to respond to mouse events like entering, exiting, and moving. The view enhances its appearance on hover and adjusts its corner radius based on the mouse's position within the view, providing a subtle interactive effect.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/AppKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
class InteractiveGlassView: NSGlassEffectView {
    
    override init(frame frameRect: NSRect) {
        super.init(frame: frameRect)
        setupTracking()
    }
    
    required init?(coder: NSCoder) {
        super.init(coder: coder)
        setupTracking()
    }
    
    private func setupTracking() {
        let options: NSTrackingArea.Options = [.mouseEnteredAndExited, .mouseMoved, .activeInActiveApp]
        let trackingArea = NSTrackingArea(rect: bounds, options: options, owner: self, userInfo: nil)
        addTrackingArea(trackingArea)
    }
    
    override func mouseEntered(with event: NSEvent) {
        super.mouseEntered(with: event)
        // Enhance the glass effect on hover
        NSAnimationContext.runAnimationGroup {
            context in
            context.duration = 0.2
            animator().tintColor = NSColor.systemBlue.withAlphaComponent(0.2)
        }
    }
    
    override func mouseExited(with event: NSEvent) {
        super.mouseExited(with: event)
        // Restore original appearance
        NSAnimationContext.runAnimationGroup {
            context in
            context.duration = 0.2
            animator().tintColor = nil
        }
    }
    
    override func mouseMoved(with event: NSEvent) {
        super.mouseMoved(with: event)
        // Create subtle interactive effects based on mouse position
        let locationInView = convert(event.locationInWindow, from: nil)
        let normalizedX = locationInView.x / bounds.width
        let normalizedY = locationInView.y / bounds.height
        
        // Example: Adjust corner radius based on mouse position
        let newRadius = 8.0 + (normalizedX * 8.0)
        cornerRadius = newRadius
    }
}
```

import SwiftUI

struct ContentView: View {
    @State private var isExpanded: Bool = false
    @Namespace private var namespace

    var body: some View {
        VStack {
            GlassEffectContainer(spacing: 40.0) {
                HStack(spacing: 40.0) {
                    Image(systemName: "scribble.variable")
                        .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)

                        .glassEffectID("pencil", in: namespace)

                            .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
                            .font(.system(size: 36))
                            .glassEffect()
                            .glassEffectID("eraser", in: namespace)
                    }
                }
            }

            Button("Toggle") {
                withAnimation {
                    isExpanded.toggle()
                }
            }
            .buttonStyle(.glass)
        }
        .padding()
    }
}

TITLE: Create Toolbar with Liquid Glass Effect in Swift
DESCRIPTION: This Swift function demonstrates how to set up a macOS window with a custom toolbar that features a liquid glass effect. It involves creating an `NSWindow`, configuring an `NSToolbar`, and adding an `NSGlassEffectView` to the window's content view to achieve the desired visual effect. The code also includes placeholder implementations for `NSToolbarDelegate` methods.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/AppKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
func setupToolbarWithGlassEffect() {
    // Create a window
    let window = NSWindow(contentRect: NSRect(x: 0, y: 0, width: 800, height: 600),
                         styleMask: [.titled, .closable, .miniaturizable, .resizable],
                         backing: .buffered,
                         defer: false)
    
    // Create a custom toolbar
    let toolbar = NSToolbar(identifier: "GlassToolbar")
    toolbar.displayMode = .iconAndLabel
    toolbar.delegate = self // Implement NSToolbarDelegate
    
    // Set the toolbar on the window
    window.toolbar = toolbar
    
    // Create a glass effect view for the toolbar area
    let toolbarHeight: CGFloat = 50.0
    let glassView = NSGlassEffectView(frame: NSRect(x: 0, y: window.contentView!.bounds.height - toolbarHeight,
                                                  width: window.contentView!.bounds.width, height: toolbarHeight))
    glassView.autoresizingMask = [.width, .minYMargin]
    
    // Add the glass view to the window's content view
    window.contentView?.addSubview(glassView)
    
    // Make the window visible
    window.makeKeyAndOrderFront(nil)
}

// Implement NSToolbarDelegate methods
extension MyViewController: NSToolbarDelegate {
    func toolbar(_ toolbar: NSToolbar, itemForItemIdentifier itemIdentifier: NSToolbarItem.Identifier, willBeInsertedIntoToolbar flag: Bool) -> NSToolbarItem? {
        // Create toolbar items
        let item = NSToolbarItem(itemIdentifier: itemIdentifier)
        item.label = "Action"
        item.image = NSImage(systemSymbolName: "star.fill", accessibilityDescription: nil)
        item.action = #selector(toolbarItemClicked(_:))
        return item
    }
    
    func toolbarDefaultItemIdentifiers(_ toolbar: NSToolbar) -> [NSToolbarItem.Identifier] {
        return ["item1", "item2", "item3"].map { NSToolbarItem.Identifier($0) }
    }
    
    func toolbarAllowedItemIdentifiers(_ toolbar: NSToolbar) -> [NSToolbarItem.Identifier] {
        return toolbarDefaultItemIdentifiers(toolbar)
    }
    
    @objc func toolbarItemClicked(_ sender: Any) {
        // Handle toolbar item clicks
    }
}
```

TITLE: Create NSGlassEffectContainerView with Multiple Glass Views (Swift)
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to set up an NSGlassEffectContainerView to hold and manage multiple NSGlassEffectView instances. It configures the container's spacing to control the merging effect of adjacent glass views and adds labels to each glass view, centering them using Auto Layout constraints.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/AppKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
func setupGlassContainer() {
    // Create a container view
    let containerView = NSGlassEffectContainerView(frame: NSRect(x: 20, y: 20, width: 400, height: 200))
    
    // Set spacing to control when glass effects merge
    containerView.spacing = 40.0
    
    // Create a content view to hold our glass views
    let contentView = NSView(frame: containerView.bounds)
    contentView.autoresizingMask = [.width, .height]
    containerView.contentView = contentView
    
    // Create first glass view
    let glassView1 = NSGlassEffectView(frame: NSRect(x: 20, y: 50, width: 150, height: 100))
    glassView1.cornerRadius = 12.0
    let label1 = NSTextField(labelWithString: "Glass View 1")
    label1.translatesAutoresizingMaskIntoConstraints = false
    glassView1.contentView = label1
    
    // Create second glass view
    let glassView2 = NSGlassEffectView(frame: NSRect(x: 190, y: 50, width: 150, height: 100))
    glassView2.cornerRadius = 12.0
    let label2 = NSTextField(labelWithString: "Glass View 2")
    label2.translatesAutoresizingMaskIntoConstraints = false
    glassView2.contentView = label2
    
    // Add glass views to the content view
    contentView.addSubview(glassView1)
    contentView.addSubview(glassView2)
    
    // Center labels in their respective glass views
    if let contentView1 = glassView1.contentView, let contentView2 = glassView2.contentView {
        NSLayoutConstraint.activate([
            label1.centerXAnchor.constraint(equalTo: contentView1.centerXAnchor),
            label1.centerYAnchor.constraint(equalTo: contentView1.centerYAnchor),
            label2.centerXAnchor.constraint(equalTo: contentView2.centerXAnchor),
            label2.centerYAnchor.constraint(equalTo: contentView2.centerYAnchor)
        ])
    }
    
    // Add the container to your view hierarchy
    view.addSubview(containerView)
}
```

TITLE: Create a Reusable Glass Card View (Swift)
DESCRIPTION: This Swift code defines a reusable `GlassCardView` class that utilizes `UIVisualEffectView` to create a glass-like appearance. It allows customization of tint color and interactivity, and provides a method to add content views to the card.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/UIKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
class GlassCardView: UIView {
    private let visualEffectView: UIVisualEffectView
    private let contentView = UIView()
    
    init(frame: CGRect, tintColor: UIColor? = nil, isInteractive: Bool = false) {
        let glassEffect = UIGlassEffect()
        glassEffect.tintColor = tintColor
        glassEffect.isInteractive = isInteractive
        
        visualEffectView = UIVisualEffectView(effect: glassEffect)
        
        super.init(frame: frame)
        
        setupViews()
    }
    
    required init?(coder: NSCoder) {
        let glassEffect = UIGlassEffect()
        visualEffectView = UIVisualEffectView(effect: glassEffect)
        
        super.init(coder: coder)
        
        setupViews()
    }
    
    private func setupViews() {
        visualEffectView.frame = bounds
        visualEffectView.autoresizingMask = [.flexibleWidth, .flexibleHeight]
        visualEffectView.layer.cornerRadius = 20
        visualEffectView.clipsToBounds = true
        addSubview(visualEffectView)
        
        contentView.frame = bounds
        contentView.autoresizingMask = [.flexibleWidth, .flexibleHeight]
        contentView.backgroundColor = .clear
        addSubview(contentView)
    }
    
    func addContent(_ view: UIView) {
        view.frame = contentView.bounds
        view.autoresizingMask = [.flexibleWidth, .flexibleHeight]
        contentView.addSubview(view)
    }
}

// Usage:
let cardView = GlassCardView(
    frame: CGRect(x: 50, y: 100, width: 300, height: 200),
    tintColor: UIColor.systemBlue.withAlphaComponent(0.2),
    isInteractive: true
)

let label = UILabel()
label.text = "Glass Card"
label.textAlignment = .center
label.textColor = .white
cardView.addContent(label)

view.addSubview(cardView)
```

TITLE: Create Basic Glass Effect View in AppKit
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create and configure a basic NSGlassEffectView in an AppKit application. It includes setting up a content view (NSTextField) and adding it to the view hierarchy.

import AppKit

class MyViewController: NSViewController {
    override func viewDidLoad() {
        super.viewDidLoad()
        
        // Create a glass effect view
        let glassView = NSGlassEffectView(frame: NSRect(x: 20, y: 20, width: 200, height: 100))
        
        // Create content to display inside the glass effect
        let label = NSTextField(labelWithString: "Liquid Glass")
        label.translatesAutoresizingMaskIntoConstraints = false
        label.font = NSFont.systemFont(ofSize: 16, weight: .medium)
        label.textColor = .white

        glassView.contentView = label

                label.centerXAnchor.constraint(equalTo: contentView.centerXAnchor),
                label.centerYAnchor.constraint(equalTo: contentView.centerYAnchor)
            ])
        }
        
        // Add the glass view to your view hierarchy
        view.addSubview(glassView)
    }
}

TITLE: Animate Glass Views within NSGlassEffectContainerView (Swift)
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to animate the position of glass views within an NSGlassEffectContainerView using Swift's animation framework. By changing the frame of a glass view, this example demonstrates how the container's spacing property can trigger merging effects between adjacent glass views.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/AppKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
func animateGlassViews() {
    // Assuming we have glassView1 and glassView2 in a container
    
    NSAnimationContext.runAnimationGroup { context in
        context.duration = 0.5
        context.timingFunction = CAMediaTimingFunction(name: .easeInEaseOut)
        
        // Animate the position of glassView2 to move closer to glassView1
        // This will trigger the merging effect when they get within the container's spacing
        glassView2.animator().frame = NSRect(x: 100, y: 50, width: 150, height: 100)
    }
}
```

TITLE: Create Custom Glass Button with Hover Effect (Swift)
DESCRIPTION: Implements a custom NSButton subclass in Swift that features a glass effect using NSGlassEffectView. It includes hover effects that change the tint color of the glass view when the mouse enters or exits the button area. The button is configured with rounded bezels and no border.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/AppKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
class GlassButton: NSButton {
    private let glassView = NSGlassEffectView()
    
    override init(frame frameRect: NSRect) {
        super.init(frame: frameRect)
        setupGlassEffect()
    }
    
    required init?(coder: NSCoder) {
        super.init(coder: coder)
        setupGlassEffect()
    }
    
    private func setupGlassEffect() {
        // Configure the button
        self.title = "Glass Button"
        self.bezelStyle = .rounded
        self.isBordered = false
        
        // Configure the glass view
        glassView.frame = self.bounds
        glassView.autoresizingMask = [.width, .height]
        glassView.cornerRadius = 8.0
        
        // Insert the glass view below the button's content
        self.addSubview(glassView, positioned: .below, relativeTo: nil)
    }
    
    override func updateTrackingAreas() {
        super.updateTrackingAreas()
        
        // Add tracking area for hover effects
        let options: NSTrackingArea.Options = [.mouseEnteredAndExited, .activeInActiveApp]
        let trackingArea = NSTrackingArea(rect: bounds, options: options, owner: self, userInfo: nil)
        addTrackingArea(trackingArea)
    }
    
    override func mouseEntered(with event: NSEvent) {
        super.mouseEntered(with: event)
        // Change appearance on hover
        NSAnimationContext.runAnimationGroup { context in
            context.duration = 0.2
            glassView.animator().tintColor = NSColor.systemBlue.withAlphaComponent(0.2)
        }
    }
    
    override func mouseExited(with event: NSEvent) {
        super.mouseExited(with: event)
        // Restore original appearance
        NSAnimationContext.runAnimationGroup { context in
            context.duration = 0.2
            glassView.animator().tintColor = nil
        }
    }
}
```

TITLE: Handle Mouse Events with NSGlassEffectView in Swift
DESCRIPTION: This Swift code defines an `InteractiveGlassView` that inherits from `NSGlassEffectView`. It sets up tracking areas to respond to mouse events like entering, exiting, and moving. The view enhances its appearance on hover and adjusts its corner radius based on the mouse's position within the view, providing a subtle interactive effect.

SOURCE: https://github.com/artemnovichkov/xcode-26-system-prompts/blob/main/AdditionalDocumentation/AppKit-Implementing-Liquid-Glass-Design.md

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
class InteractiveGlassView: NSGlassEffectView {
    
    override init(frame frameRect: NSRect) {
        super.init(frame: frameRect)
        setupTracking()
    }
    
    required init?(coder: NSCoder) {
        super.init(coder: coder)
        setupTracking()
    }
    
    private func setupTracking() {
        let options: NSTrackingArea.Options = [.mouseEnteredAndExited, .mouseMoved, .activeInActiveApp]
        let trackingArea = NSTrackingArea(rect: bounds, options: options, owner: self, userInfo: nil)
        addTrackingArea(trackingArea)
    }
    
    override func mouseEntered(with event: NSEvent) {
        super.mouseEntered(with: event)
        // Enhance the glass effect on hover
        NSAnimationContext.runAnimationGroup {
            context in
            context.duration = 0.2
            animator().tintColor = NSColor.systemBlue.withAlphaComponent(0.2)
        }
    }
    
    override func mouseExited(with event: NSEvent) {
        super.mouseExited(with: event)
        // Restore original appearance
        NSAnimationContext.runAnimationGroup {
            context in
            context.duration = 0.2
            animator().tintColor = nil
        }
    }
    
    override func mouseMoved(with event: NSEvent) {
        super.mouseMoved(with: event)
        // Create subtle interactive effects based on mouse position
        let locationInView = convert(event.locationInWindow, from: nil)
        let normalizedX = locationInView.x / bounds.width
        let normalizedY = locationInView.y / bounds.height
        
        // Example: Adjust corner radius based on mouse position
        let newRadius = 8.0 + (normalizedX * 8.0)
        cornerRadius = newRadius
    }
}
```

TITLE: SwiftUI Button Style: glass(_:)
DESCRIPTION: Applies a configurable Liquid Glass effect to a button based on its context. This style can be customized with a tint or variant.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/primitivebuttonstyle/glass%28_%3A%29

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
## Type Method

### `glass(_:)`

A button style that applies a configurable Liquid Glass effect based on the button’s context.

**Platforms:** iOS 26.0+, iPadOS 26.0+, Mac Catalyst 26.0+, macOS 26.0+, tvOS 26.0+, watchOS 26.0+

### Method

`static func glass(_ glass: Glass) -> Self`

### Description

This button style applies a Liquid Glass effect that you can customize by specifying a tint or variant. In the following example, the button renders using the clear variant of Liquid Glass:

```swift
Button("Button") {}
    .buttonStyle(.glass(.clear))
```

In tvOS, this button style applies a Liquid Glass effect regardless of whether the button has focus. This style is similar to the `bordered` style.

To apply this style to a button, or to a view that contains buttons, use the `buttonStyle(_:)` modifier.
```

## SwiftUI Glass Button Style

### Description
Applies a Liquid Glass effect to a button based on its context. This style is available on iOS, iPadOS, Mac Catalyst, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS starting from version 26.0.

### Method
Static property access

### Endpoint

    // Action

.buttonStyle(.glass)

### Response
#### Success Response (200)

#### Response Example

// No direct response body for style application, the effect is visual.

### Discussion
In tvOS, this button style consistently applies a Liquid Glass effect, irrespective of the button's focus state. To implement this style, use the `buttonStyle(_:)` modifier on a `Button` or a container view containing buttons.

TITLE: Swift: Animating Badges and Toggle with Liquid Glass Morph Effect
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the implementation of the Liquid Glass morph effect for animating badges and a toggle button. It involves organizing elements within a `GlassEffectContainer`, assigning `glassEffectID` to each badge and the button, and using `withAnimation` to trigger the morphing animation when the `isExpanded` state changes.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/landmarks-displaying-custom-activity-badges

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
// Organizes the badges and toggle button to animate together.
GlassEffectContainer(spacing: Constants.badgeGlassSpacing) {
    VStack(alignment: .center, spacing: Constants.badgeButtonTopSpacing) {
        if isExpanded {
            VStack(spacing: Constants.badgeSpacing) {
                ForEach(modelData.earnedBadges) {
                    BadgeLabel(badge: $0)
                        // Adds Liquid Glass to the badge.
                        .glassEffect(.regular, in: .rect(cornerRadius: Constants.badgeCornerRadius))
                        // Adds an identifier to the badge for animation.
                        .glassEffectID($0.id, in: namespace)
                }
            }
        }


        Button {
            // Animates this button and badges when `isExpanded` changes values.
            withAnimation {
                isExpanded.toggle()
            }
        } label: {
            ToggleBadgesLabel(isExpanded: isExpanded)
                .frame(width: Constants.badgeShowHideButtonWidth,
                       height: Constants.badgeShowHideButtonHeight)
        }
        // Adds Liquid Glass to the button.
        .buttonStyle(.glass)
        #if os(macOS)
        .tint(.clear)
        #endif
        // Adds an identifier to the button for animation.
        .glassEffectID("togglebutton", in: namespace)
    }
    .frame(width: Constants.badgeFrameWidth)
}
```

TITLE: Get GlassProminentButtonStyle

TITLE: Morph Liquid Glass effects during transitions
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use `glassEffectID(_:in:)` and `GlassEffectTransition` for morphing effects between views with Liquid Glass. It shows an example of morphing an eraser image into a pencil image based on a state change.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/applying-liquid-glass-to-custom-views

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
## Morph Liquid Glass effects during transitions

Morphing effects occur during transitions or animations between views with Liquid Glass effects. Coordinate transitions between views with effects in a container by using the `glassEffectID(_:in:)` modifier. `GlassEffectTransition` allows you to specify the type of transition to use when you want to add or remove effects within a container. For effects you want to add or remove that are positioned within the container’s assigned spacing, the default transition type is `matchedGeometry`.

If you prefer to have a simpler transition or to create a custom transition, use the `materialize` transition and `withAnimation(_:_:)`. Use the `materialize` transition for effects you want to add or remove that are farther from each other than the container’s assigned spacing. To provide people with a consistent experience, use `matchedGeometry` and `materialize` transitions across your apps. The system applies more than opacity changes with the available transition types.

Associate each Liquid Glass effect with a unique identifier within a namespace that the `Namespace` property wrapper provides. These IDs ensure SwiftUI animates the same shapes correctly when a shape appears or disappears due to view hierarchy changes. SwiftUI uses the spacing provided to the effect container along with the geometry of the shapes themselves to determine when and which appropriate shapes to morph into and out of.

The `glassEffectID(_:in:)` and `glassEffectTransition(_:)` modifiers only affect their content during view hierarchy transitions or animations.

### Example Usage

```swift
import SwiftUI

struct ContentView: View {
    @State private var isExpanded: Bool = false
    @Namespace private var namespace

    var body: some View {
        VStack {
            GlassEffectContainer(spacing: 40.0) {
                HStack(spacing: 40.0) {
                    Image(systemName: "scribble.variable")
                        .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
                        .font(.system(size: 36))
                        .glassEffect()
                        .glassEffectID("pencil", in: namespace)

                    if isExpanded {
                        Image(systemName: "eraser.fill")
                            .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
                            .font(.system(size: 36))
                            .glassEffect()
                            .glassEffectID("eraser", in: namespace)
                    }
                }
            }

            Button("Toggle") {
                withAnimation {
                    isExpanded.toggle()
                }
            }
            .buttonStyle(.glass)
        }
    }
}

// Preview Provider
struct ContentView_Previews: PreviewProvider {
    static var previews: some View {
        ContentView()
    }
}

// Extension for Glass button style
extension ButtonStyle where Self == GlassButtonStyle {
    static var glass: GlassButtonStyle { GlassButtonStyle() }
}
```

### Modifiers

- `glassEffectID(_:in:)`: Associates a Liquid Glass effect with a unique identifier within a namespace for correct animation during view hierarchy transitions.
- `glassEffectTransition(_:)`: Specifies the transition type for adding or removing effects within a container.

### Key Structures

- `GlassEffectContainer`: A view that enables morphing between multiple Liquid Glass shapes.
- `GlassEffectTransition`: Defines changes applied when a glass effect is added or removed.
```

## struct Glass

### Description
A structure that defines the configuration of the Liquid Glass material.

### Usage
You provide instances of a variant of Liquid Glass to the `glassEffect(_:in:)` view modifier.

```swift
Text("Hello, World!")
    .font(.title)
    .padding()
    .glassEffect()
```

You can combine Liquid Glass effects using a `GlassEffectContainer`.

### Instance Methods
- `func interactive(Bool) -> Glass`: Returns a copy of the structure configured to be interactive.
- `func tint(Color?) -> Glass`: Returns a copy of the structure with a configured tint color.

### Type Properties
- `static var clear: Glass`: The clear variant of glass.
- `static var identity: Glass`: The identity variant of glass. When applied, your content remains unaffected as if no glass effect was applied.
- `static var regular: Glass`: The regular variant of the Liquid Glass material.

### Conforms To
- `Equatable`
- `Sendable
- `SendableMetatype`
```

TITLE: Optimize performance when using Liquid Glass effects
DESCRIPTION: Provides guidance on optimizing performance when using Liquid Glass effects. It advises limiting the number of effects and using Instruments for UI performance analysis.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/applying-liquid-glass-to-custom-views

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
## Optimize performance when using Liquid Glass effects

Creating too many Liquid Glass effect containers and applying too many effects to views outside of containers can degrade performance. Limit the use of Liquid Glass effects onscreen at the same time. Additionally, optimize how your app spends rendering time as people use it. To learn how to improve the performance of your UI, see Explore UI animation hitches and the render loop and Optimize SwiftUI performance with Instruments.

### Recommendations

- **Limit Concurrent Effects**: Reduce the number of Liquid Glass effects displayed simultaneously.
- **Profile Performance**: Utilize Instruments, specifically "Core Animation" and "SwiftUI Performance", to identify and resolve UI animation hitches and render loop issues.
```

TITLE: GlassEffectContainer API
DESCRIPTION: This section details the GlassEffectContainer struct and its related modifiers and types for applying Liquid Glass effects in SwiftUI.

LANGUAGE: APIDOC

## Struct: GlassEffectContainer

### Description
A view that combines multiple Liquid Glass shapes into a single shape that can morph individual shapes into one another.

### Generics
* `Content` - A type conforming to `View`.

### Supported Platforms
* iOS 26.0+
* iPadOS 26.0+
* Mac Catalyst 26.0+
* macOS 26.0+
* tvOS 26.0+
* watchOS 26.0+

### Declaration
```swift
@MainActor @preconcurrency
struct GlassEffectContainer<Content>
where Content : View
```

### Overview
Use a container with the `glassEffect(_:in:)` modifier. Each view with a Liquid Glass effect contributes a shape rendered with the effect to a set of shapes. SwiftUI renders the effects together, improving rendering performance and allowing the effects to interact with and morph into one another.

Configure how shapes interact with one another by customizing the default spacing value of the container. As shapes near one another, their paths start to blend into one another. The higher the spacing, the sooner blending begins as the shapes approach each other.

### Initializers
#### `init(spacing: CGFloat?, content: () -> Content)`
Creates a glass effect container with the provided spacing, extracting glass shapes from the provided content.

### Relationships
#### Conforms To
* `Sendable`
* `SendableMetatype`
* `View`

### See Also
* **Styling views with Liquid Glass**: Applying Liquid Glass to custom views
* **Landmarks: Building an app with Liquid Glass**: Enhance your app experience with system-provided and custom Liquid Glass.

## Modifiers and Related Types

### `func glassEffect(Glass, in: some Shape) -> some View`
Applies the Liquid Glass effect to a view.

### `func interactive(Bool) -> Glass`
Returns a copy of the structure configured to be interactive.

### `struct GlassEffectTransition`
A structure that describes changes to apply when a glass effect is added or removed from the view hierarchy.

### `struct GlassButtonStyle`
A button style that applies glass border artwork based on the button’s context.

### `struct GlassProminentButtonStyle`
A button style that applies prominent glass border artwork based on the button’s context.

### `struct DefaultGlassEffectShape`
The default shape applied by glass effects, a capsule.
```

## GlassEffectTransition

### Description
A structure that describes changes to apply when a glass effect is added or removed from the view hierarchy.

### Type Properties

- `static var identity: GlassEffectTransition`
  The identity transition specifying no changes.
- `static var matchedGeometry: GlassEffectTransition`
  Returns the matched geometry glass effect transition.
- `static var materialize: GlassEffectTransition`
  The materialize glass effect transition which will fade in content and animate in or out the glass material but will not attempt to match the geometry of any other glass effects.

### Relationships

#### Conforms To

- `Sendable`
- `SendableMetatype`

### See Also

#### Styling views with Liquid Glass
- Applying Liquid Glass to custom views
- Configure, combine, and morph views using Liquid Glass effects.
- Landmarks: Building an app with Liquid Glass
- Enhance your app experience with system-provided and custom Liquid Glass.

#### Methods

- `func glassEffect(Glass, in: some Shape) -> some View`
  Applies the Liquid Glass effect to a view.
- `func interactive(_:) -> Glass`
  Returns a copy of the structure configured to be interactive.

#### Structs

- `struct GlassEffectContainer`
  A view that combines multiple Liquid Glass shapes into a single shape that can morph individual shapes into one another.
- `struct GlassButtonStyle`
  A button style that applies glass border artwork based on the button’s context.
- `struct GlassProminentButtonStyle`
  A button style that applies prominent glass border artwork based on the button’s context.
- `struct DefaultGlassEffectShape`
  The default shape applied by glass effects, a capsule.

TITLE: Swift: Animating Badges and Toggle with Liquid Glass Morph Effect
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the implementation of the Liquid Glass morph effect for animating badges and a toggle button. It involves organizing elements within a `GlassEffectContainer`, assigning `glassEffectID` to each badge and the button, and using `withAnimation` to trigger the morphing animation when the `isExpanded` state changes.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/landmarks-displaying-custom-activity-badges

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
// Organizes the badges and toggle button to animate together.
GlassEffectContainer(spacing: Constants.badgeGlassSpacing) {
    VStack(alignment: .center, spacing: Constants.badgeButtonTopSpacing) {
        if isExpanded {
            VStack(spacing: Constants.badgeSpacing) {
                ForEach(modelData.earnedBadges) {
                    BadgeLabel(badge: $0)
                        // Adds Liquid Glass to the badge.
                        .glassEffect(.regular, in: .rect(cornerRadius: Constants.badgeCornerRadius))
                        // Adds an identifier to the badge for animation.
                        .glassEffectID($0.id, in: namespace)
                }
            }
        }


        Button {
            // Animates this button and badges when `isExpanded` changes values.
            withAnimation {
                isExpanded.toggle()
            }
        } label: {
            ToggleBadgesLabel(isExpanded: isExpanded)
                .frame(width: Constants.badgeShowHideButtonWidth,
                       height: Constants.badgeShowHideButtonHeight)
        }
        // Adds Liquid Glass to the button.
        .buttonStyle(.glass)
        #if os(macOS)
        .tint(.clear)
        #endif
        // Adds an identifier to the button for animation.
        .glassEffectID("togglebutton", in: namespace)
    }
    .frame(width: Constants.badgeFrameWidth)
}
```

TITLE: Morph Liquid Glass effects during transitions
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use `glassEffectID(_:in:)` and `GlassEffectTransition` for morphing effects between views with Liquid Glass. It shows an example of morphing an eraser image into a pencil image based on a state change.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/applying-liquid-glass-to-custom-views

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
## Morph Liquid Glass effects during transitions

Morphing effects occur during transitions or animations between views with Liquid Glass effects. Coordinate transitions between views with effects in a container by using the `glassEffectID(_:in:)` modifier. `GlassEffectTransition` allows you to specify the type of transition to use when you want to add or remove effects within a container. For effects you want to add or remove that are positioned within the container’s assigned spacing, the default transition type is `matchedGeometry`.

If you prefer to have a simpler transition or to create a custom transition, use the `materialize` transition and `withAnimation(_:_:)`. Use the `materialize` transition for effects you want to add or remove that are farther from each other than the container’s assigned spacing. To provide people with a consistent experience, use `matchedGeometry` and `materialize` transitions across your apps. The system applies more than opacity changes with the available transition types.

Associate each Liquid Glass effect with a unique identifier within a namespace that the `Namespace` property wrapper provides. These IDs ensure SwiftUI animates the same shapes correctly when a shape appears or disappears due to view hierarchy changes. SwiftUI uses the spacing provided to the effect container along with the geometry of the shapes themselves to determine when and which appropriate shapes to morph into and out of.

The `glassEffectID(_:in:)` and `glassEffectTransition(_:)` modifiers only affect their content during view hierarchy transitions or animations.

### Example Usage

```swift
import SwiftUI

struct ContentView: View {
    @State private var isExpanded: Bool = false
    @Namespace private var namespace

    var body: some View {
        VStack {
            GlassEffectContainer(spacing: 40.0) {
                HStack(spacing: 40.0) {
                    Image(systemName: "scribble.variable")
                        .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
                        .font(.system(size: 36))
                        .glassEffect()
                        .glassEffectID("pencil", in: namespace)

                    if isExpanded {
                        Image(systemName: "eraser.fill")
                            .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
                            .font(.system(size: 36))
                            .glassEffect()
                            .glassEffectID("eraser", in: namespace)
                    }
                }
            }

            Button("Toggle") {
                withAnimation {
                    isExpanded.toggle()
                }
            }
            .buttonStyle(.glass)
        }
    }
}

// Preview Provider
struct ContentView_Previews: PreviewProvider {
    static var previews: some View {
        ContentView()
    }
}

// Extension for Glass button style
extension ButtonStyle where Self == GlassButtonStyle {
    static var glass: GlassButtonStyle { GlassButtonStyle() }
}
```

### Modifiers

- `glassEffectID(_:in:)`: Associates a Liquid Glass effect with a unique identifier within a namespace for correct animation during view hierarchy transitions.
- `glassEffectTransition(_:)`: Specifies the transition type for adding or removing effects within a container.

### Key Structures

- `GlassEffectContainer`: A view that enables morphing between multiple Liquid Glass shapes.
- `GlassEffectTransition`: Defines changes applied when a glass effect is added or removed.
```

## struct Glass

### Description
A structure that defines the configuration of the Liquid Glass material.

### Usage
You provide instances of a variant of Liquid Glass to the `glassEffect(_:in:)` view modifier.

```swift
Text("Hello, World!")
    .font(.title)
    .padding()
    .glassEffect()
```

You can combine Liquid Glass effects using a `GlassEffectContainer`.

### Instance Methods
- `func interactive(Bool) -> Glass`: Returns a copy of the structure configured to be interactive.
- `func tint(Color?) -> Glass`: Returns a copy of the structure with a configured tint color.

### Type Properties
- `static var clear: Glass`: The clear variant of glass.
- `static var identity: Glass`: The identity variant of glass. When applied, your content remains unaffected as if no glass effect was applied.
- `static var regular: Glass`: The regular variant of the Liquid Glass material.

### Conforms To
- `Equatable`
- `Sendable
- `SendableMetatype`
```

## func glassEffectUnion(id: namespace:)

### Description
Associates any Liquid Glass effects defined within this view to a union with the provided identifier.

### Method
Instance Method

### Endpoint
N/A (SwiftUI Framework Method)

### Parameters
#### Path Parameters
None

#### Query Parameters
None

#### Request Body
None

### Request Example
N/A

### Response
#### Success Response (N/A)
Returns `some View` with the effect applied.

#### Response Example
N/A

### Discussion
You may want the geometries of multiple views to contribute to a single Liquid Glass effect shape. In these cases, you can use a `glassEffectUnion(id:namespace:)` to specify that a view should contribute to a union of Liquid Glass effects with a particular identifier. All Liquid Glass effects with the same shape and Liquid Glass variant will be combined into a single shape.

### Supported Platforms
iOS 26.0+, iPadOS 26.0+, Mac Catalyst 26.0+, macOS 26.0+, tvOS 26.0+, watchOS 26.0+
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: GlassEffectTransition Type Properties
DESCRIPTION: Provides static properties for different types of glass effect transitions: identity (no changes), matchedGeometry, and materialize (fade in/out with material animation).

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/glasseffecttransition

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
static var identity: GlassEffectTransition
static var matchedGeometry: GlassEffectTransition
static var materialize: GlassEffectTransition
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Optimize performance when using Liquid Glass effects
DESCRIPTION: Provides guidance on optimizing performance when using Liquid Glass effects. It advises limiting the number of effects and using Instruments for UI performance analysis.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/applying-liquid-glass-to-custom-views

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
## Optimize performance when using Liquid Glass effects

Creating too many Liquid Glass effect containers and applying too many effects to views outside of containers can degrade performance. Limit the use of Liquid Glass effects onscreen at the same time. Additionally, optimize how your app spends rendering time as people use it. To learn how to improve the performance of your UI, see Explore UI animation hitches and the render loop and Optimize SwiftUI performance with Instruments.

### Recommendations

- **Limit Concurrent Effects**: Reduce the number of Liquid Glass effects displayed simultaneously.
- **Profile Performance**: Utilize Instruments, specifically "Core Animation" and "SwiftUI Performance", to identify and resolve UI animation hitches and render loop issues.
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Make Body Method for GlassButtonStyle
DESCRIPTION: The `makeBody` method for `GlassButtonStyle` creates the visual representation of a button, applying the glass effect. It takes a `Configuration` object as input.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/glassbuttonstyle

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
func makeBody(configuration: GlassButtonStyle.Configuration) -> some View
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Apply background extension effect in SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to apply a background extension effect to a featured landmark header using SwiftUI. It configures an Image to extend to the edges and applies the `backgroundExtensionEffect()` modifier. An overlay with a headline and button is added after the modifier.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/landmarks-building-an-app-with-liquid-glass

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
Image("SomeImage")
  .backgroundExtensionEffect()
  .overlay(
    VStack {
      Text("Headline")
      Button("Button") {} 
    }
  )
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Apply Liquid Glass effect to multiple views in a container - SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates using `GlassEffectContainer` with an `HStack` to apply Liquid Glass effects to multiple images. The `spacing` parameter controls how the effects blend. This example showcases how the shapes morph together as components move.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/applying-liquid-glass-to-custom-views

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
GlassEffectContainer(spacing: 40.0) {
    HStack(spacing: 40.0) {
        Image(systemName: "scribble.variable")
            .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
            .font(.system(size: 36))
            .glassEffect()


        Image(systemName: "eraser.fill")
            .frame(width: 80.0, height: 80.0)
            .font(.system(size: 36))
            .glassEffect()


            // An `offset` shows how Liquid Glass effects react to each other in a container.
            // Use animations and components appearing and disappearing to obtain effects that look purposeful.
            .offset(x: -40.0, y: 0.0)
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Define Glass Structure in SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows the basic definition of the `Glass` structure in SwiftUI, which is used to configure the Liquid Glass material.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/glass

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
struct Glass
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: GlassEffectContainer API
DESCRIPTION: This section details the GlassEffectContainer struct and its related modifiers and types for applying Liquid Glass effects in SwiftUI.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/glasseffectcontainer

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
## Struct: GlassEffectContainer

### Description
A view that combines multiple Liquid Glass shapes into a single shape that can morph individual shapes into one another.

### Generics
* `Content` - A type conforming to `View`.

### Supported Platforms
* iOS 26.0+
* iPadOS 26.0+
* Mac Catalyst 26.0+
* macOS 26.0+
* tvOS 26.0+
* watchOS 26.0+

### Declaration
```swift
@MainActor @preconcurrency
struct GlassEffectContainer<Content>
where Content : View
```

### Overview
Use a container with the `glassEffect(_:in:)` modifier. Each view with a Liquid Glass effect contributes a shape rendered with the effect to a set of shapes. SwiftUI renders the effects together, improving rendering performance and allowing the effects to interact with and morph into one another.

Configure how shapes interact with one another by customizing the default spacing value of the container. As shapes near one another, their paths start to blend into one another. The higher the spacing, the sooner blending begins as the shapes approach each other.

### Initializers
#### `init(spacing: CGFloat?, content: () -> Content)`
Creates a glass effect container with the provided spacing, extracting glass shapes from the provided content.

### Relationships
#### Conforms To
* `Sendable`
* `SendableMetatype`
* `View`

### See Also
* **Styling views with Liquid Glass**: Applying Liquid Glass to custom views
* **Landmarks: Building an app with Liquid Glass**: Enhance your app experience with system-provided and custom Liquid Glass.

## Modifiers and Related Types

### `func glassEffect(Glass, in: some Shape) -> some View`
Applies the Liquid Glass effect to a view.

### `func interactive(Bool) -> Glass`
Returns a copy of the structure configured to be interactive.

### `struct GlassEffectTransition`
A structure that describes changes to apply when a glass effect is added or removed from the view hierarchy.

### `struct GlassButtonStyle`
A button style that applies glass border artwork based on the button’s context.

### `struct GlassProminentButtonStyle`
A button style that applies prominent glass border artwork based on the button’s context.

### `struct DefaultGlassEffectShape`
The default shape applied by glass effects, a capsule.
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: GlassButtonStyle Structure
DESCRIPTION: Defines the structure for the GlassButtonStyle in SwiftUI, which is used to apply glass border artwork to buttons based on their context.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/glassbuttonstyle

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
struct GlassButtonStyle
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Organize toolbar items with ToolbarSpacer and ToolbarItemGroup in SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to organize toolbar items into logical groupings using `ToolbarSpacer` and `ToolbarItemGroup` in SwiftUI. It divides the toolbar into sections to improve appearance and utility. This is applicable for iOS 26.0+, iPadOS 26.0+, macOS 26.0+, and Xcode 26.0+.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/landmarks-refining-the-system-provided-glass-effect-in-toolbars

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
.toolbar {
    ToolbarSpacer(.flexible)

    ToolbarItem {
        ShareLink(item: landmark, preview: landmark.sharePreview)
    }

    ToolbarSpacer(.fixed)
    
    ToolbarItemGroup {
        LandmarkFavoriteButton(landmark: landmark)
        LandmarkCollectionsMenu(landmark: landmark)
    }
    
    ToolbarSpacer(.fixed)

    ToolbarItem {
        Button("Info", systemImage: "info") {
            modelData.selectedLandmark = landmark
            modelData.isLandmarkInspectorPresented.toggle()
        }
    }
}
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Configure Tint Color for Glass Effect in SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to set a custom tint color for the `Glass` effect using the `tint(_:)` instance method. This modifies the color appearance of the applied glass material.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/glass

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
func tint(_: Color?) -> Glass
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: SwiftUI glassEffectTransition(_:)
DESCRIPTION: Associates a glass effect transition with any glass effects defined within this view. This modifier is used with `glassEffect(_:in:)` and `GlassEffectContainer` to animate changes to glass effects.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/view/glasseffecttransition%28_%3A%29

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
## func glassEffectTransition(_:)

### Description
Associates a glass effect transition with any glass effects defined within this view.

### Method
Instance Method

### Parameters
#### Request Body
- **transition** (GlassEffectTransition) - The transition to apply to the glass effect.

### Request Example
```swift
.glassEffectTransition(.matchedGeometry)
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
- **some View** (View) - The view with the glass effect transition applied.

### Response Example
```swift
// Example usage within a view:
var body: some View {
    Image(systemName: "note")
        .glassEffect()
        .glassEffectID("note", in: namespace)
        .glassEffectTransition(.matchedGeometry)
}
```

### Availability
iOS 26.0+
iPadOS 26.0+
Mac Catalyst 26.0+
macOS 26.0+
tvOS 26.0+
watchOS 26.0+
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: SwiftUI GlassEffectContainer init(spacing:content:)
DESCRIPTION: Creates a glass effect container with the provided spacing and content. Supports iOS, iPadOS, Mac Catalyst, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS version 26.0 and later.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/glasseffectcontainer/init%28spacing%3Acontent%3A%29

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
## init(spacing:content:)

### Description
Creates a glass effect container with the provided spacing, extracting glass shapes from the provided content.

### Method
`init`

### Parameters
#### Path Parameters
None

#### Query Parameters
None

#### Request Body
- **spacing** (`CGFloat?`) - Optional - The spacing between elements within the container.
- **content** (`() -> Content`) - Required - A closure that returns the content views to be placed inside the container. The `@ViewBuilder` attribute allows for multiple views to be passed.

### Request Example
```swift
GlassEffectContainer(spacing: 10) {
    Text("View 1")
    Text("View 2")
}
```

### Response
#### Success Response (200)
This initializer does not return a value in the traditional sense; it constructs a `GlassEffectContainer` view.

#### Response Example
N/A
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: GlassBackgroundDisplayMode Cases - SwiftUI
DESCRIPTION: Provides the possible cases for the GlassBackgroundDisplayMode enumeration. Each case dictates a specific behavior for displaying the glass material.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/glassbackgrounddisplaymode

LANGUAGE: swift
CODE:
```
case always
case implicit
case never
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: GlassEffectTransition
DESCRIPTION: Describes changes to apply when a glass effect is added or removed from the view hierarchy. Available on iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/glasseffecttransition

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
## GlassEffectTransition

### Description
A structure that describes changes to apply when a glass effect is added or removed from the view hierarchy.

### Type Properties

- `static var identity: GlassEffectTransition`
  The identity transition specifying no changes.
- `static var matchedGeometry: GlassEffectTransition`
  Returns the matched geometry glass effect transition.
- `static var materialize: GlassEffectTransition`
  The materialize glass effect transition which will fade in content and animate in or out the glass material but will not attempt to match the geometry of any other glass effects.

### Relationships

#### Conforms To

- `Sendable`
- `SendableMetatype`

### See Also

#### Styling views with Liquid Glass
- Applying Liquid Glass to custom views
- Configure, combine, and morph views using Liquid Glass effects.
- Landmarks: Building an app with Liquid Glass
- Enhance your app experience with system-provided and custom Liquid Glass.

#### Methods

- `func glassEffect(Glass, in: some Shape) -> some View`
  Applies the Liquid Glass effect to a view.
- `func interactive(_:) -> Glass`
  Returns a copy of the structure configured to be interactive.

#### Structs

- `struct GlassEffectContainer`
  A view that combines multiple Liquid Glass shapes into a single shape that can morph individual shapes into one another.
- `struct GlassButtonStyle`
  A button style that applies glass border artwork based on the button’s context.
- `struct GlassProminentButtonStyle`
  A button style that applies prominent glass border artwork based on the button’s context.
- `struct DefaultGlassEffectShape`
  The default shape applied by glass effects, a capsule.
```

--------------------------------

TITLE: Glass Effect Related Functions and Structures
DESCRIPTION: Details on functions and structures related to applying glass effects to views.

SOURCE: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/SwiftUI/documentation/swiftui/glassbuttonstyle

LANGUAGE: APIDOC
CODE:
```
## Glass Effect Functions and Structures

DESCRIPTION: Defines the structure for GlassProminentButtonStyle, which conforms to PrimitiveButtonStyle. This style is used to apply prominent glass border artwork to buttons.

## Summary

I've created a complete implementation plan for migrating to real iOS 26 Liquid Glass APIs based on official Apple documentation. Here's what needs to be done:

### **Key Changes**
1. **LiquidGlassCard.swift** - Replace Material placeholders with `.glassEffect(.regular/.clear, in: .rect())`
2. **GlassEffectHelpers.swift** - Use system `GlassEffectContainer` and `.glassEffectID()`
3. **BrandButton.swift** - Use system `.buttonStyle(.glass)` and `.buttonStyle(.glassProminent)`
4. **DesignTokens+Extensions.swift** - Update helper to use real `.glassEffect()` API

### **Total Impact**
- **4 files** to update
- **~180 lines** changed
- **12 view files** will automatically benefit from auto-upgrade
- **Zero breaking changes** due to existing deprecation path

**Ready to implement?** I can start updating the files now, or you can review the plan first. Which would you prefer?
